intro: Lupinus densiflorus var. vastiticola, commonly known as the denseflower lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its dense clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and restoration projects.
